q: What are the symptoms of blepharitis?
a: The symptoms of blepharitis include sore eyelids, itchy eyes, a gritty feeling in the eyes, flakes or crusts around the roots of the eyelashes, and eyelids sticking together in the morning when you wake up.

q: How can I treat and prevent blepharitis?
a: To treat and prevent blepharitis, you should clean your eyelids twice a day to start with, and then once a day as your symptoms improve. You should also continue to clean your eyes, even if your symptoms clear up. It is recommended not to wear contact lenses and avoid using eye makeup, especially eyeliner and mascara, while you have symptoms.

q: How can I clean my eyes to alleviate blepharitis symptoms?
a: You can clean your eyes by soaking a clean flannel or cotton wool in warm water and placing it on your closed eyelid for 5 to 10 minutes. Then gently massage your eyelids for around 30 seconds. Clean your eyelids using cotton wool or a cotton bud, and you can use a small amount of baby shampoo in water. Finally, wipe along the edge of your eyelids to remove any flakes or crusts.

q: How can a pharmacist help with blepharitis?
a: A pharmacist might be able to suggest things to help keep your eyelids clean, including eye pads, wipes, and eye drops.

q: When should I see a GP for blepharitis?
a: You should see a GP if your blepharitis symptoms do not improve after a few weeks of cleaning your eyelids.

q: What treatment options can a GP offer for blepharitis?
a: A GP might suggest using an antibiotic cream or ointment that you rub on your eyelid if your blepharitis does not clear up after cleaning your eyelids regularly. Antibiotic eye drops or tablets may be recommended if blepharitis has caused other problems. In severe cases or if you have other eye symptoms, the GP may refer you to an eye specialist.

q: What are the common causes of blepharitis?
a: Blepharitis can be caused by a type of bacteria that lives on the skin, a skin condition such as seborrhoeic dermatitis, or the glands inside the eyelids not producing enough oil. It's important to note that blepharitis cannot be spread to other people.

q: Can blepharitis be spread to other people?
a: No, blepharitis cannot be spread to other people.
